Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of deaths by stating that two children died from the COVID-19 vaccine in Guinea, while the evidence suggests that there were no deaths related to the vaccine.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that two children died from the COVID-19 vaccine in Guinea.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the deaths mentioned in the news report from March 2019 are related to the COVID-19 vaccine, without providing any direct evidence to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there were no deaths related to the COVID-19 vaccine in Guinea, as confirmed by local government representatives and healthcare officials.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the deaths mentioned in the news report, such as other factors or causes unrelated to the vaccine.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on outdated and unrelated news reports from March 2019 to support the assertion of deaths from the COVID-19 vaccine in Guinea.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating biases in the provided claim.
